dn9:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
dn9:1.3: Now at that time the wanderer Poṭṭhapāda was residing together with three hundred wanderers in Mallikā’s single-halled monastery for philosophical debates, hedged by pale-moon ebony trees.
dn9:1.4: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
dn9:2.2: “It’s too early to wander for alms in Sāvatthī.
dn9:2.3: Why don’t I go to Mallikā’s monastery to visit the wanderer Poṭṭhapāda?”
dn9:3.1: Now at that time, Poṭṭhapāda was sitting together with a large assembly of wanderers making an uproar, a dreadful racket. They engaged in all kinds of low talk, such as
dn9:3.2: talk about kings, bandits, and ministers; talk about armies, threats, and wars; talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds; talk about garlands and fragrances; talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries; talk about women and heroes; street talk and well talk; talk about the departed; motley talk; tales of land and sea; and talk about being reborn in this or that place.
dn9:4.1: Poṭṭhapāda saw the Buddha coming off in the distance,
dn9:4.3: “Be quiet, good fellows, don’t make a sound.
dn9:4.5: The venerable likes quiet and praises quiet.
dn9:4.6: Hopefully if he sees that our assembly is quiet he’ll see fit to approach.”
dn9:5.4: Welcome to the Blessed One, sir!
dn9:5.5: It’s been a long time since you took the opportunity to come here.
dn9:5.6: Please, sir, sit down, this seat is ready.”
dn9:5.7: The Buddha sat on the seat spread out,
dn9:5.8: while Poṭṭhapāda took a low seat and sat to one side.
dn9:5.10: “Poṭṭhapāda, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was left unfinished?”
dn9:6.1: When he said this, the wanderer Poṭṭhapāda said to the Buddha,
dn9:6.2: “Sir, leave aside what we were sitting talking about just now.
dn9:6.3: It won’t be hard for you to hear about that later.
dn9:6.4: Sir, a few days ago several ascetics and brahmins who follow various other religions were sitting together at the debating hall, and a discussion about the cessation of perception came up among them:
dn9:6.5: ‘How does the cessation of perception happen?’
dn9:6.7: ‘A person’s perceptions arise and cease without cause or reason.
dn9:6.8: When they arise, you become percipient.
dn9:6.9: When they cease, you become non-percipient.’
dn9:6.10: That’s how some describe the cessation of perception.
dn9:6.12: ‘That’s not how it is, good fellows!
dn9:6.15: When it enters, you become percipient.
dn9:6.16: When it departs, you become non-percipient.’
dn9:6.17: That’s how some describe the cessation of perception.
dn9:6.19: ‘That’s not how it is, good fellows!
dn9:6.20: There are ascetics and brahmins of great power and might.
dn9:6.21: They insert and extract a person’s perception.
dn9:6.22: When they insert it, you become percipient.
dn9:6.23: When they extract it, you become non-percipient.’
dn9:6.24: That’s how some describe the cessation of perception.
dn9:6.26: ‘That’s not how it is, good fellows!
dn9:6.27: There are deities of great power and might.
dn9:6.28: They insert and extract a person’s perception.
dn9:6.29: When they insert it, you become percipient.
dn9:6.30: When they extract it, you become non-percipient.’
dn9:6.31: That’s how some describe the cessation of perception.
dn9:6.32: That reminded me of the Buddha:
dn9:6.33: ‘Surely it must be the Blessed One, the Holy One who is so very skilled in such matters.’
dn9:6.34: The Buddha is skilled and well-versed concerning the cessation of perception.
dn9:6.35: How does the cessation of perception happen?”
dn9:7.1: “Regarding this, Poṭṭhapāda, those ascetics and brahmins who say that
dn9:7.2: a person’s perceptions arise and cease without cause or reason are wrong from the start.
dn9:7.4: Because a person’s perceptions arise and cease with cause and reason.
dn9:7.5: With training, certain perceptions arise and certain perceptions cease.
dn9:7.6: And what is that training?” said the Buddha.
dn9:7.7: “It’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.
dn9:7.7.1.2: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
dn9:7.7.1.3: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
dn9:7.7.2.1: A householder hears that teaching, or a householder’s child, or someone reborn in a good family.
dn9:7.7.2.2: They gain faith in the Realized One
dn9:7.7.2.4: ‘Life at home is cramped and dirty, life gone forth is wide open.
dn9:7.7.2.5: It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
dn9:7.7.2.6: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
dn9:7.7.2.7: After some time they give up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. They shave off hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
dn9:7.7.3.1: Once they’ve gone forth, they live restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken. They act skillfully by body and speech. They’re purified in livelihood and accomplished in ethical conduct. They guard the sense doors, have mindfulness and situational awareness, and are content.
dn9:7.7.4.1: And how, Poṭṭhapāda, is a mendicant accomplished in ethics?
dn9:7.7.4.2: It’s when a mendicant gives up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of sympathy for all living beings.
dn9:7.7.4.4: They give up stealing. They take only what’s given, and expect only what’s given. They keep themselves clean by not thieving.
dn9:7.7.4.6: They give up unchastity. They are chaste, set apart, avoiding the vulgar act of sex.
dn9:7.7.5.1: They give up lying. They speak the truth and stick to the truth. They’re honest and dependable, and don’t trick the world with their words.
dn9:7.7.5.3: They give up divisive speech. They don’t repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, they reconcile those who are divided, supporting unity, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.
dn9:7.7.5.5: They give up harsh speech. They speak in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people.
dn9:7.7.5.7: They give up talking nonsense. Their words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. They say things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.
dn9:7.7.6.1: They refrain from injuring plants and seeds.
dn9:7.7.6.2: They eat in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and food at the wrong time.
dn9:7.7.6.3: They refrain from seeing shows of dancing, singing, and music .
dn9:7.7.6.4: They refrain from beautifying and adorning themselves with garlands, fragrance, and makeup.
dn9:7.7.6.5: They refrain from high and luxurious beds.
dn9:7.7.6.6: They refrain from receiving gold and currency,
dn9:7.7.6.15: They refrain from running errands and messages;
dn9:7.7.6.19: mutilation, murder, abduction, banditry, plunder, and violence.
dn9:7.7.6.21: The shorter section on ethics is finished.
dn9:7.7.7.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in injuring plants and seeds.
dn9:7.7.7.2: These include plants propagated from roots, stems, cuttings, or joints; and those from regular seeds as the fifth. They refrain from such injury to plants and seeds.
dn9:7.7.8.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in storing up goods for their own use.
dn9:7.7.8.2: This includes such things as food, drink, clothes, vehicles, bedding, fragrance, and things of the flesh.
dn9:7.7.8.3: They refrain from storing up such goods.
dn9:7.7.9.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in seeing shows.
dn9:7.7.9.2: This includes such things as dancing, singing, music, performances, and storytelling; clapping, gongs, and kettledrums; beauty pageants; pole-acrobatics and bone-washing displays of the corpse-workers; battles of elephants, horses, buffaloes, bulls, goats, rams, chickens, and quails; staff-fights, boxing, and wrestling; combat, roll calls of the armed forces, battle-formations, and regimental reviews.
dn9:7.7.10.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in gambling that causes negligence.
dn9:7.7.10.2: This includes such things as checkers with eight or ten rows, checkers in the air, hopscotch, spillikins, board-games, tip-cat, drawing straws, dice, leaf-flutes, toy plows, somersaults, pinwheels, toy measures, toy carts, toy bows, guessing words from syllables, guessing another’s thoughts, and imitating musical instruments.
dn9:7.7.11.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still make use of high and luxurious bedding.
dn9:7.7.11.2: This includes such things as sofas, couches, woolen covers—shag-piled, colorful, white, embroidered with flowers, quilted, embroidered with animals, double-or single-fringed—and silk covers studded with gems, as well as silken sheets, woven carpets, rugs for elephants, horses, or chariots, antelope hide rugs, and spreads of fine deer hide, with a canopy above and red cushions at both ends.
dn9:7.7.12.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in beautifying and adorning themselves with garlands, fragrance, and makeup.
dn9:7.7.12.2: This includes such things as applying beauty products by anointing, massaging, bathing, and rubbing; mirrors, ointments, garlands, fragrances, and makeup; face-powder, foundation, bracelets, headbands, fancy walking-sticks or containers, rapiers, parasols, fancy sandals, turbans, jewelry, chowries, and long-fringed white robes.
dn9:7.7.12.3: They refrain from such beautification and adornment.
dn9:7.7.13.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in low talk.
dn9:7.7.13.2: This includes such topics as talk about kings, bandits, and ministers; talk about armies, threats, and wars; talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds; talk about garlands and fragrances; talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries; talk about women and heroes; street talk and well talk; talk about the departed; motley talk; tales of land and sea; and talk about being reborn in this or that place.
dn9:7.7.13.3: They refrain from such low talk.
dn9:7.7.14.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in arguments.
dn9:7.7.14.2: They say such things as: ‘You don’t understand this teaching and training. I understand this teaching and training. What, you understand this teaching and training? You’re practicing wrong. I’m practicing right. I stay on topic, you don’t. You said last what you should have said first. You said first what you should have said last. What you’ve thought so much about has been disproved. Your doctrine is refuted. Go on, save your doctrine! You’re trapped; get yourself out of this—if you can!’
dn9:7.7.14.3: They refrain from such argumentative talk.
dn9:7.7.15.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in running errands and messages.
dn9:7.7.15.2: This includes running errands for rulers, ministers, aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or princes who say: ‘Go here, go there. Take this, bring that from there.’
dn9:7.7.16.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in deceit, flattery, hinting, and belittling, and using material things to chase after other material things. They refrain from such deceit and flattery.
dn9:7.7.16.3: The middle section on ethics is finished.
dn9:7.7.17.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low lore, by wrong livelihood.
dn9:7.7.17.2: This includes such fields as limb-reading, omenology, divining celestial portents, interpreting dreams, divining bodily marks, divining holes in cloth gnawed by mice, fire offerings, ladle offerings, offerings of husks, rice powder, rice, ghee, or oil; offerings from the mouth, blood sacrifices, palmistry; geomancy for building sites, fields, and cemeteries; exorcisms, earth magic, snake charming, poisons; the lore of the scorpion, the rat, the bird, and the crow; prophesying lifespan, chanting for protection, and divining omens from wild animals.
dn9:7.7.17.3: They refrain from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.
dn9:7.7.18.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low lore, by wrong livelihood.
dn9:7.7.18.2: This includes reading the marks of gems, cloth, clubs, swords, spears, arrows, bows, weapons, women, men, boys, girls, male and female bondservants, elephants, horses, buffaloes, bulls, cows, goats, rams, chickens, quails, monitor lizards, rabbits, tortoises, or deer.
dn9:7.7.18.3: They refrain from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.
dn9:7.7.19.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low lore, by wrong livelihood.
dn9:7.7.19.2: This includes making predictions that the king will march forth or march back; or that our king will attack and the enemy king will retreat, or vice versa; or that our king will triumph and the enemy king will be defeated, or vice versa; and so there will be victory for one and defeat for the other.
dn9:7.7.19.3: They refrain from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.
dn9:7.7.20.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low lore, by wrong livelihood.
dn9:7.7.20.2: This includes making predictions that there will be an eclipse of the moon, or sun, or stars; that the sun, moon, and stars will be in conjunction or in opposition; that there will be a meteor shower, a fiery sky, an earthquake, or thunder in the heavens; that there will be a rising, a setting, a darkening, a brightening of the moon, sun, and stars. And it also includes making predictions about the results of all such phenomena.
dn9:7.7.20.3: They refrain from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.
dn9:7.7.21.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low lore, by wrong livelihood.
dn9:7.7.21.2: This includes predicting whether there will be plenty of rain or drought; plenty to eat or famine; an abundant harvest or a bad harvest; security or peril; sickness or health. It also includes such occupations as arithmetic, accounting, calculating, poetry, and cosmology.
dn9:7.7.21.3: They refrain from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.
dn9:7.7.22.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low lore, by wrong livelihood.
dn9:7.7.22.2: This includes making arrangements for giving and taking in marriage; for engagement and divorce; and for scattering rice inwards or outwards at the wedding ceremony. It also includes casting spells for good or bad luck, treating impacted fetuses, binding the tongue, or locking the jaws; charms for the hands and ears; questioning a mirror, a girl, or a god as an oracle; worshiping the sun, worshiping the Great One, breathing fire, and invoking Siri, the goddess of luck.
dn9:7.7.22.3: They refrain from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.
dn9:7.7.23.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low lore, by wrong livelihood.
dn9:7.7.23.2: This includes rites for propitiation, for granting wishes, for ghosts, for the earth, for rain, for property settlement, and for preparing and consecrating house sites, and rites involving rinsing and bathing, and oblations. It also includes administering emetics, purgatives, expectorants, and phlegmagogues; administering ear-oils, eye restoratives, nasal medicine, ointments, and counter-ointments; surgery with needle and scalpel, treating children, prescribing root medicines, and binding on herbs.
dn9:7.7.23.3: They refrain from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.
dn9:7.7.24.1: A mendicant thus accomplished in ethics sees no danger in any quarter in regards to their ethical restraint.
dn9:7.7.24.2: It’s like a king who has defeated his enemies. He sees no danger from his foes in any quarter.
dn9:7.7.24.3: In the same way, a mendicant thus accomplished in ethics sees no danger in any quarter in regards to their ethical restraint.
dn9:7.7.24.4: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, they experience a blameless happiness inside themselves.
dn9:7.8: That’s how a mendicant is accomplished in ethics.
dn9:7.8.1.6: The longer section on ethics is finished.
dn9:7.8.2.1: And how does a mendicant guard the sense doors?
dn9:7.8.2.2: When a mendicant sees a sight with their eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
dn9:7.8.2.3: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving its restraint.
dn9:7.8.2.4: When they hear a sound with their ears …
dn9:7.8.2.5: When they smell an odor with their nose …
dn9:7.8.2.6: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …
dn9:7.8.2.7: When they feel a touch with their body …
dn9:7.8.2.8: When they know an idea with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
dn9:7.8.2.9: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint.
dn9:7.8.2.10: When they have this noble sense restraint, they experience an unsullied bliss inside themselves.
dn9:7.8.2.11: That’s how a mendicant guards the sense doors.
dn9:7.8.3.1: And how does a mendicant have mindfulness and situational awareness?
dn9:7.8.3.2: It’s when a mendicant acts with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.
dn9:7.8.3.3: That’s how a mendicant has mindfulness and situational awareness.
dn9:7.8.4.1: And how is a mendicant content?
dn9:7.8.4.2: It’s when a mendicant is content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.
dn9:7.8.4.3: They’re like a bird: wherever it flies, wings are its only burden.
dn9:7.8.4.4: In the same way, a mendicant is content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.
dn9:7.8.4.5: That’s how a mendicant is content.
dn9:8.1.1.1: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, this noble sense restraint, this noble mindfulness and situational awareness, and this noble contentment,
dn9:8.1.1.2: they frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
dn9:8.1.1.3: After the meal, they return from almsround, sit down cross-legged, set their body straight, and establish mindfulness in their presence.
dn9:8.1.2.1: Giving up covetousness for the world, they meditate with a heart rid of covetousness, cleansing the mind of covetousness.
dn9:8.1.2.2: Giving up ill will and malevolence, they meditate with a mind rid of ill will, full of sympathy for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will.
dn9:8.1.2.3: Giving up dullness and drowsiness, they meditate with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness.
dn9:8.1.2.4: Giving up restlessness and remorse, they meditate without restlessness, their mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse.
dn9:8.1.2.5: Giving up doubt, they meditate having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.
dn9:8.1.3.1: Suppose a man who has gotten into debt were to apply himself to work,
dn9:8.1.3.3: He would pay off the original loan and have enough left over to support his partner.
dn9:8.1.3.8: he’d be filled with joy and happiness.
dn9:8.1.4.1: Suppose there was a person who was sick, suffering, gravely ill. They’d lose their appetite and get physically weak.
dn9:8.1.4.2: But after some time they’d recover from that illness, and regain their appetite and their strength.
dn9:8.1.4.8: they’d be filled with joy and happiness.
dn9:8.1.5.1: Suppose a person was imprisoned in a jail.
dn9:8.1.5.2: But after some time they were released from jail, safe and sound, with no loss of wealth.
dn9:8.1.5.6: they’d be filled with joy and happiness.
dn9:8.1.6.1: Suppose a person was a bondservant. They would not be their own master, but indentured to another, unable to go where they wish.
dn9:8.1.6.2: But after some time they’d be freed from servitude. They would be their own master, not indentured to another, an emancipated individual able to go where they wish.
dn9:8.1.6.6: they’d be filled with joy and happiness.
dn9:8.1.7.1: Suppose there was a person with wealth and property who was traveling along a desert road, which was perilous, with nothing to eat.
dn9:8.1.7.2: But after some time they crossed over the desert safely, arriving within a village, a sanctuary free of peril.
dn9:8.1.7.6: they’d be filled with joy and happiness.
dn9:8.1.8.1: In the same way, as long as these five hindrances are not given up inside themselves, a mendicant regards them thus as a debt, a disease, a prison, slavery, and a desert crossing.
dn9:8.1.8.2: But when these five hindrances are given up inside themselves, a mendicant regards this as freedom from debt, good health, release from prison, emancipation, and a place of sanctuary at last.
dn9:9.1: Seeing that the hindrances have been given up in them, joy springs up. Being joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, they feel bliss. And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed.
dn9:10.1: Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
dn9:10.2: The sensual perception that they had previously ceases.
dn9:10.3: At that time they have a subtle and true perception of the rapture and bliss born of seclusion.
dn9:10.4: That’s how, with training, certain perceptions arise and certain perceptions cease.
dn9:10.5: And this is that training,” said the Buddha.
dn9:11.1: “Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
dn9:11.2: The subtle and true perception of the rapture and bliss born of seclusion that they had previously ceases.
dn9:11.3: At that time they have a subtle and true perception of the rapture and bliss born of immersion.
dn9:11.4: That’s how, with training, certain perceptions arise and certain perceptions cease.
dn9:11.5: And this is that training,” said the Buddha.
dn9:12.1: “Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
dn9:12.2: The subtle and true perception of the rapture and bliss born of immersion that they had previously ceases.
dn9:12.3: At that time they have a subtle and true perception of bliss with equanimity.
dn9:12.4: That’s how, with training, certain perceptions arise and certain perceptions cease.
dn9:12.5: And this is that training,” said the Buddha.
dn9:13.1: “Furthermore, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
dn9:13.2: The subtle and true perception of bliss with equanimity that they had previously ceases.
dn9:13.3: At that time they have a subtle and true perception of neutral feeling.
dn9:13.4: That’s how, with training, certain perceptions arise and certain perceptions cease.
dn9:13.5: And this is that training,” said the Buddha.
dn9:14.1: “Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space.
dn9:14.2: The perception of luminous form that they had previously ceases.
dn9:14.3: At that time they have a subtle and true perception of the dimension of infinite space.
dn9:14.4: That’s how, with training, certain perceptions arise and certain perceptions cease.
dn9:14.5: And this is that training,” said the Buddha.
dn9:15.1: “Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite consciousness.
dn9:15.2: The subtle and true perception of the dimension of infinite space that they had previously ceases.
dn9:15.3: At that time they have a subtle and true perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness.
dn9:15.4: That’s how, with training, certain perceptions arise and certain perceptions cease.
dn9:15.5: And this is that training,” said the Buddha.
dn9:16.1: “Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness.
dn9:16.2: The subtle and true perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness that they had previously ceases.
dn9:16.3: At that time they have a subtle and true perception of the dimension of nothingness.
dn9:16.4: That’s how, with training, certain perceptions arise and certain perceptions cease.
dn9:16.5: And this is that training,” said the Buddha.
dn9:17.1: “Poṭṭhapāda, from the time a mendicant here takes charge of their own perception, they proceed from one stage to the next, progressively reaching the peak of perception.
dn9:17.2: Standing on the peak of perception they think,
dn9:17.3: ‘Intentionality is bad for me, it’s better to be free of it.
dn9:17.4: For if I were to intend and choose, these perceptions would cease in me, and other coarser perceptions would arise.
dn9:17.5: Why don’t I neither make a choice nor form an intention?’
dn9:17.6: They neither make a choice nor form an intention.
dn9:17.7: Those perceptions cease in them, and other coarser perceptions don’t arise.
dn9:17.9: And that, Poṭṭhapāda, is how the progressive cessation of perception is attained with awareness.
dn9:18.2: Have you ever heard of this before?”
dn9:18.4: This is how I understand what the Buddha said:
dn9:18.5: ‘From the time a mendicant here takes charge of their own perception, they proceed from one stage to the next, progressively reaching the peak of perception.
dn9:18.6: Standing on the peak of perception they think,
dn9:18.7: “Intentionality is bad for me, it’s better to be free of it.
dn9:18.8: For if I were to intend and choose, these perceptions would cease in me, and other coarser perceptions would arise.
dn9:18.9: Why don’t I neither make a choice nor form an intention?”
dn9:18.10: Those perceptions cease in them, and other coarser perceptions don’t arise.
dn9:18.12: And that is how the progressive cessation of perception is attained with awareness.’”
dn9:19.1: “Does the Buddha describe just one peak of perception, or many?”
dn9:19.2: “I describe the peak of perception as both one and many.”
dn9:19.3: “But sir, how do you describe it as one peak and as many?”
dn9:19.4: “I describe the peak of perception according to the specific manner in which one touches cessation.
dn9:19.5: That’s how I describe the peak of perception as both one and many.”
dn9:20.1: “But sir, does perception arise first and knowledge afterwards? Or does knowledge arise first and perception afterwards? Or do they both arise at the same time?”
dn9:20.2: “Perception arises first and knowledge afterwards. The arising of perception leads to the arising of knowledge.
dn9:20.4: ‘My knowledge arose from a specific condition.’
dn9:20.5: That is a way to understand how
dn9:20.6: perception arises first and knowledge afterwards; that the arising of perception leads to the arising of knowledge.”
dn9:21.1: “Sir, is perception a person’s self, or are perception and self different things?”
dn9:21.2: “But Poṭṭhapāda, do you believe in a self?”
dn9:21.3: “I believe in a solid self, sir, which is formed, made up of the four principal states, and consumes solid food.”
dn9:21.4: “Suppose there were such a solid self, Poṭṭhapāda. In that case, perception would be one thing, the self another.
dn9:21.5: Here is another way to understand how perception and self are different things.
dn9:21.6: So long as that solid self remains, still some perceptions arise in a person and others cease.
dn9:21.7: That is a way to understand how perception and self are different things.”
dn9:22.1: “Sir, I believe in a mind-made self which is whole in its major and minor limbs, not deficient in any faculty.”
dn9:22.2: “Suppose there were such a mind-made self, Poṭṭhapāda. In that case, perception would be one thing, the self another.
dn9:22.3: Here is another way to understand how perception and self are different things.
dn9:22.4: So long as that mind-made self remains, still some perceptions arise in a person and others cease.
dn9:22.5: That too is a way to understand how perception and self are different things.”
dn9:23.1: “Sir, I believe in a formless self which is made of perception.”
dn9:23.2: “Suppose there were such a formless self, Poṭṭhapāda. In that case, perception would be one thing, the self another.
dn9:23.3: Here is another way to understand how perception and self are different things.
dn9:23.4: So long as that formless self remains, still some perceptions arise in a person and others cease.
dn9:23.5: That too is a way to understand how perception and self are different things.”
dn9:24.1: “But, sir, am I able to know whether
dn9:24.2: perception is a person’s self, or whether perception and self are different things?”
dn9:24.3: “It’s hard for you to understand this, since you have a different view, creed, and belief, unless you dedicate yourself to practice with the guidance of tradition.”
dn9:25.3: then what do you make of this: ‘The cosmos is eternal. This is the only truth, anything else is futile’?”
dn9:25.4: “This has not been declared by me, Poṭṭhapāda.”
dn9:26.1: “Then what do you make of this: ‘The cosmos is not eternal. This is the only truth, anything else is futile’?”
dn9:26.2: “This too has not been declared by me.”
dn9:27.1: “Then what do you make of this: ‘The cosmos is finite …’ …
dn9:27.3: ‘The soul and the body are the same thing …’ …
dn9:27.4: ‘The soul and the body are different things …’ …
dn9:27.5: ‘A realized one still exists after death …’ …
dn9:27.6: ‘A realized one no longer exists after death …’ …
dn9:27.7: ‘A realized one both still exists and no longer exists after death …’ …
dn9:27.8: ‘A Realized One neither still exists nor no longer exists after death. This is the only truth, anything else is futile’?”
dn9:27.9: “This too has not been declared by me.”
dn9:28.1: “Why haven’t these things been declared by the Buddha?”
dn9:28.2: “Because they’re not beneficial or relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. They don’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
dn9:28.3: That’s why I haven’t declared them.”
dn9:29.1: “Then what has been declared by the Buddha?”
dn9:29.2: “I have declared this: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.”
dn9:30.1: “Why have these things been declared by the Buddha?”
dn9:30.2: “Because they are beneficial and relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. They lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
dn9:30.3: That’s why I have declared them.”
dn9:30.4: “That’s so true, Blessed One! That’s so true, Holy One!
dn9:30.5: Please, sir, go at your convenience.”
dn9:30.6: Then the Buddha got up from his seat and left.
dn9:31.1: Soon after the Buddha left, those wanderers beset Poṭṭhapāda on all sides with sneering and jeering.
dn9:31.2: “No matter what the ascetic Gotama says, Poṭṭhapāda agrees with him:
dn9:31.3: ‘That’s so true, Blessed One! That’s so true, Holy One!’
dn9:31.4: We understand that the ascetic Gotama didn’t give any categorical teaching at all regarding whether the cosmos is eternal and so on.”
dn9:31.6: When they said this, Poṭṭhapāda said to them,
dn9:31.7: “I too understand that the ascetic Gotama didn’t give any categorical teaching at all regarding whether the cosmos is eternal and so on.
dn9:31.10: Nevertheless, the practice that he describes is true, real, and accurate. It is the regularity of natural principles, the invariance of natural principles.
dn9:31.11: So how could a sensible person such as I not agree that what was well spoken by the ascetic Gotama was in fact well spoken?”
dn9:32.1: Then after two or three days had passed, Citta Hatthisāriputta and Poṭṭhapāda went to see the Buddha. Citta Hatthisāriputta bowed and sat down to one side.
dn9:32.2: But the wanderer Poṭṭhapāda exchanged greetings with the Buddha, and when the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.
dn9:32.3: Poṭṭhapāda told the Buddha what had happened after he left. The Buddha said:
dn9:33.1: “All those wanderers, Poṭṭhapāda, are blind and sightless.
dn9:33.2: You are the only one whose eyes are clear.
dn9:33.3: For I have taught and pointed out teachings that are categorical
dn9:33.4: and also teachings that are not categorical.
dn9:33.5: And what teachings have I taught and pointed out as not categorical?
dn9:33.10: ‘The soul is the same thing as the body’ …
dn9:33.11: ‘The soul and the body are different things’ …
dn9:33.12: ‘A realized one still exists after death’ …
dn9:33.13: ‘A realized one no longer exists after death’ …
dn9:33.14: ‘A realized one both still exists and no longer exists after death’ …
dn9:33.15: ‘A realized one neither still exists nor no longer exists after death.’
dn9:33.16: And why have I taught and pointed out such teachings as not categorical?
dn9:33.17: Because those things aren’t beneficial or relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. They don’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
dn9:33.18: That’s why I have taught and pointed out such teachings as not categorical.
dn9:33.20: And what teachings have I taught and pointed out as categorical?
dn9:33.21: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
dn9:33.25: And why have I taught and pointed out such teachings as categorical?
dn9:33.26: Because they are beneficial and relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. They lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
dn9:33.27: That’s why I have taught and pointed out such teachings as categorical.
dn9:34.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
dn9:34.2: ‘The self is perfectly happy and free of disease after death.’
dn9:34.3: I go up to them and say,
dn9:34.4: ‘Is it really true that this is the venerables’ view?’
dn9:34.8: ‘But do you meditate knowing and seeing a perfectly happy world?’
dn9:34.11: ‘But have you perceived a perfectly happy self for a single day or night, or even half a day or night?’
dn9:34.15: a path and a practice to realize a perfectly happy world?’
dn9:34.18: ‘But have you ever heard the voice of the deities reborn in a perfectly happy world saying,
dn9:34.19: “Practice well, good fellows, practice directly so as to realize a perfectly happy world.
dn9:34.20: For this is how we practiced, and we were reborn in a perfectly happy world”?’
dn9:34.23: This being so, doesn’t what they say turn out to have no demonstrable basis?”
dn9:35.1: “Suppose, Poṭṭhapāda, a man were to say:
dn9:35.2: ‘Whoever the finest lady in the land is, it is her that I want, her that I desire!’

dn9:39.1: “Poṭṭhapāda, there are these three kinds of reincarnation in a life-form:
dn9:39.2: a solid  life-form, a mind-made life-form, and a formless life-form.
dn9:39.3: And what is reincarnation in a solid life-form?
dn9:39.4: It is formed, made up of the four principal states, and consumes solid food.
dn9:39.5: What is reincarnation in a mind-made life-form?
dn9:39.6: It is formed, mind-made, whole in its major and minor limbs, not deficient in any faculty.
dn9:39.7: What is reincarnation in a formless life-form?
dn9:39.8: It is formless, made of perception.
dn9:40.1: I teach the Dhamma for the giving up of reincarnation in these three kinds of life-form.
dn9:40.2: ‘When you practice accordingly, corrupting qualities will be given up in you and cleansing qualities will grow. You’ll enter and remain in the fullness and abundance of wisdom, having realized it with your own insight in this very life.’
dn9:40.4: ‘Corrupting qualities will be given up and cleansing qualities will grow. One will enter and remain in the fullness and abundance of wisdom, having realized it with one’s own insight in this very life. But such a life is suffering.’
dn9:40.5: But you should not see it like this.
dn9:40.6: Corrupting qualities will be given up and cleansing qualities will grow. One will enter and remain in the fullness and abundance of wisdom, having realized it with one’s own insight in this very life. dn9:43.1: Poṭṭhapāda, if others should ask us,

dn9:44.2: ‘But reverends, what is that reincarnation in a mind-made life-form?’ We’d answer like this,

dn9:54.1: When he had spoken, the wanderer Poṭṭhapāda said to the Buddha,
dn9:54.3: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, so too the Buddha has made the teaching clear in many ways.

dn9:55.1: But Citta Hatthisāriputta said to the Buddha,

dn9:56.1: And Citta Hatthisāriputta received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.
dn9:56.2: Not long after his ordination, Venerable Citta Hatthisāriputta, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
dn9:56.3: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”
dn9:56.4: And Venerable Citta Hatthisāriputta became one of the perfected.
